question: What allegations has Epic Games made against Apple in their lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California?
answer: Epic Games has made allegations against Apple in their lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California, claiming violations of federal and state antitrust laws, as well as California’s unfair competition law, based on the operation of Apple's App Store. The District Court ruled in favor of Apple on nine out of ten counts in Epic's claim, but found that certain provisions of Apple's App Store Review Guidelines violated California’s unfair competition law. The court issued an injunction preventing Apple from prohibiting developers from including external links in their apps that direct customers to purchasing mechanisms other than Apple's in-app purchasing.

Apple Inc. | Q2 2024 Form 10-Q | 18

PART II — OTHER INFORMATION

Item 1.

Legal Proceedings

Digital Markets Act Investigations

On March 25, 2024, the European Commission (the “Commission”) announced that it had opened two formal noncompliance investigations against the Company under the European Union (“EU”) Digital Markets Act (the “DMA”). The Commission’s investigations concern (1) Article 5(4) of the DMA, which relates to how developers may communicate and promote offers to end users for apps distributed through the App Store as well as how developers may conclude contracts with those end users; and (2) Article 6(3) of the DMA, which relates to default settings, uninstallation of apps, and a web browser choice screen on iOS. If the Commission concludes that there has been a violation, it can issue a cease and desist order and may impose fines up to 10% of the Company’s annual worldwide net sales. Although any decision by the Commission can be appealed to the General Court of the EU, the effectiveness of the Commission’s order would apply immediately while the appeal is pending, unless a stay of the order is granted. The Company believes that it complies with the DMA and will continue to engage with the Commission as it conducts its investigations.

Department of Justice Lawsuit

On March 21, 2024, the U.S. Department of Justice (the “DOJ”) and 16 state and district attorneys general filed a civil antitrust lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Company alleging monopolization or attempted monopolization in the markets for “performance smartphones” and “smartphones” in violation of U.S. antitrust laws. The DOJ is seeking equitable relief to redress the alleged anticompetitive behavior. In addition, various civil litigation matters have been filed in state and federal courts in the U.S. alleging similar violations of U.S. antitrust laws and seeking monetary damages and other nonmonetary relief. The Company believes it has substantial defenses and intends to vigorously defend itself.

Epic Games

Epic Games, Inc. (“Epic”) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (the “California District Court”) against the Company alleging violations of federal and state antitrust laws and California’s unfair competition law based upon the Company’s operation of its App Store. The California District Court found that certain provisions of the Company’s App Store Review Guidelines violate California’s unfair competition law and issued an injunction enjoining the Company from prohibiting developers from including in their apps external links that direct customers to purchasing mechanisms other than Apple in-app purchasing. The injunction applies to apps on the U.S. storefront of the iOS and iPadOS® App Store. On January 16, 2024, the Company implemented a plan to comply with the injunction and filed a statement of compliance with the California District Court. On March 13, 2024, Epic filed a motion with the California District Court disputing the Company’s compliance plan and seeking to enforce the injunction. The Company has filed an opposition to Epic’s motion. The Company believes it has substantial defenses and intends to vigorously defend itself.

Other Legal Proceedings

The Company is subject to other legal proceedings and claims that have not been fully resolved and that have arisen in the ordinary course of business. The Company settled certain matters during the second quarter of 2024 that did not individually or in the aggregate have a material impact on the Company’s financial condition or operating results. The outcome of litigation is inherently uncertain. If one or more legal matters were resolved against the Company in a reporting period for amounts above management’s expectations, the Company’s financial condition and operating results for that reporting period could be materially adversely affected.

Item 1A. Risk Factors

The Company’s business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition and stock price can be affected by a number of factors, whether currently known or unknown, including those described in Part I, Item 1A of the 2023 Form 10-K under the heading “Risk Factors.” When any one or more of these risks materialize from time to time, the Company’s business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition and stock price can be materially and adversely affected. Except as set forth below, there have been no material changes to the Company’s risk factors since the 2023 Form 10-K.

The technology industry, including, in some instances, the Company, is subject to intense media, political and regulatory']
ground_truth: Epic Games, Inc. (“Epic”) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against the Company alleging violations of federal and state antitrust laws and California’s unfair competition law based upon the Company’s operation of its App Store. The California District Court found that certain provisions of the Company’s App Store Review Guidelines violate California’s unfair competition law and issued an injunction enjoining the Company from prohibiting developers from including in their apps external links that direct customers to purchasing mechanisms other than Apple in-app purchasing.

question: How is shareholders' equity calculated and what components are included in it?
answer:
Shareholders' equity is calculated as the total of several components, which typically include:

1. **Common Stock and Additional Paid-in Capital**: This represents the funds raised by the company through the issuance of shares. It includes the par value of the shares issued and any additional amount paid by investors over the par value.

2. **Retained Earnings (or Accumulated Deficit)**: This is the cumulative amount of net income that has been retained in the company rather than paid out as dividends. If the company has incurred losses, this can result in an accumulated deficit.

3. **Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income (Loss)**: This includes other comprehensive income items that are not included in net income, such as foreign currency translation adjustments, unrealized gains or losses on investments, and pension plan adjustments.

In the case of Apple Inc., the total shareholders' equity at the end of the reporting period is calculated by summing these components. For example, as of September 30, 2023, Apple reported total shareholders' equity of $62,146 million, which includes the ending balances of common stock and additional paid-in capital, retained earnings, and accumulated other comprehensive income/loss.

ground_truth: Shareholders' equity is calculated by subtracting total liabilities from total assets. The components included in shareholders' equity are common stock and additional paid-in capital, retained earnings or accumulated deficit, and accumulated other comprehensive loss.

question: How does the company adjust its cost in relation to unrealized gains and losses in its financial statements?
answer:
The company adjusts its cost in relation to unrealized gains and losses by reporting these adjustments in its financial statements under the categories of "Adjusted Cost," "Unrealized Gains," and "Unrealized Losses." The adjusted cost reflects the original cost of the assets, while unrealized gains and losses represent the changes in the fair value of those assets that have not yet been realized through sales.

For example, as of September 30, 2023, the company reported total adjusted costs of $173,752 million, with unrealized gains of $30 million and unrealized losses of $(11,683) million. The fair value of the assets, which includes these adjustments, is reported as $162,099 million. This method allows the company to provide a clear picture of the current valuation of its assets while still maintaining a record of their original cost.

Derivative Instruments and Hedging

The Company may use derivative instruments to partially offset its business exposure to foreign exchange and interest rate risk. However, the Company may choose not to hedge certain exposures for a variety of reasons, including accounting considerations or the prohibitive economic cost of hedging particular exposures. There can be no assurance the hedges will offset more than a portion of the financial impact resulting from movements in foreign exchange or interest rates.

Foreign Exchange Rate Risk

To protect gross margins from fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, the Company may use forwards, options or other instruments, and may designate these instruments as cash flow hedges. The Company generally hedges portions of its forecasted foreign currency exposure associated with revenue and inventory purchases, typically for up to 12 months.

To protect the Company’s foreign currency–denominated term debt or marketable securities from fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, the Company may use forwards, cross-currency swaps or other instruments. The Company designates these instruments as either cash flow or fair value hedges. question: How does the issuance of common stock impact the shareholders' equity of Apple Inc.?
answer:
The issuance of common stock impacts the shareholders' equity of Apple Inc. in the following ways:

1. **Increase in Common Stock and Additional Paid-in Capital**: When Apple issues common stock, it increases the balances in the "Common stock and additional paid-in capital" section of shareholders' equity. For example, in the year ended September 30, 2023, Apple issued $1,346 million in common stock, which contributed to an increase in the ending balance of this category to $73,812 million.

2. **Total Shareholders' Equity**: The issuance of common stock contributes to the overall total shareholders' equity. As seen in the consolidated statements, the total shareholders' equity increased from $50,672 million at the beginning of the year to $62,146 million at the end of the year, influenced by factors such as the issuance of common stock, net income, and other adjustments.

3. **Dilution of Existing Shares**: While the issuance of new shares increases the total equity, it can also dilute the ownership percentage of existing shareholders. This means that the value of each existing share may decrease if the earnings are not sufficient to offset the increase in the number of shares outstanding.

In summary, the issuance of common stock increases the common stock and additional paid-in capital, thereby raising total shareholders' equity, but it may also dilute the ownership of existing shareholders.

question: What is the significance of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 in relation to the certification of financial reports by executives of public companies like Apple Inc.?
answer:
The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 (SOX) is significant in relation to the certification of financial reports by executives of public companies, such as Apple Inc., because it mandates that the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and Chief Financial Officer (CFO) personally certify the accuracy and completeness of the financial statements and disclosures in the company's reports. 

As indicated in the documents, both Timothy D. Cook (CEO) and Luca Maestri (CFO) certify that the Annual Report of Apple Inc. on Form 10-K complies with the requirements of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and that the information presented fairly represents the financial condition and results of operations of the company. This certification is required under Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which aims to enhance the reliability of corporate disclosures and protect investors by holding executives accountable for the accuracy of financial reporting.

In essence, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act imposes legal obligations on executives to ensure the integrity of financial reporting, thereby increasing transparency and reducing the risk of corporate fraud.
contexts:
[' requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and that information contained in such Form 10-Q fairly presents in all material respects the financial condition and results of operations of Apple Inc. at the dates and for the periods indicated.

Date: May 2, 2024

By:

/s/ Timothy D. Cook

Timothy D. Cook

Chief Executive Officer

I, Luca Maestri, certify, as of the date hereof, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that the Quarterly Report of Apple Inc. on Form 10-Q for the period ended March 30, 2024 fully complies with the requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and that information contained in such Form 10-Q fairly presents in all material respects the financial condition and results of operations of Apple Inc. at the dates and for the periods indicated.

Date: May 2, 2024

By:

/s/ Luca Maestri

Luca Maestri

Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer

A signed original of this written statement required by Section 906 has been provided to Apple Inc. and will be retained by Apple Inc. and furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission or its staff upon request.']
ground_truth: The significance of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 in relation to the certification of financial reports by executives of public companies like Apple Inc. is that it requires executives to certify that the financial statements fairly present the financial condition and results of operations of the company. This certification is done under penalty of perjury, providing greater accountability and transparency in financial reporting.

question: How do EU DMA investigations affect Apple's financial reporting and fines?
answer:
The EU Digital Markets Act (DMA) investigations can materially affect Apple's financial reporting and potential fines in several ways. Compliance with the DMA, which Apple is required to meet by March 2024, may necessitate changes to its App Store operations, including how developers interact with consumers and how Apple manages app distribution. 

If the investigations result in adverse findings against Apple, the company could face significant fines and may be required to alter its business practices related to the App Store. Such changes could adversely impact Apple's business, results of operations, and financial condition. The potential for legal proceedings and claims arising from these investigations could also lead to increased liabilities and costs, further affecting Apple's financial reporting.

Overall, the outcomes of the DMA investigations, including any fines or required operational changes, could have a substantial negative impact on Apple's financial health and market reputation.

The injunction applies to apps on the U.S. storefront of the iOS and iPadOS® App Store. On January 16, 2024, the Company implemented a plan to comply with the injunction and filed a statement of compliance with the California District Court. On March 13, 2024, Epic filed a motion with the California District Court disputing the Company’s compliance plan and seeking to enforce the injunction. The Company has filed an opposition to Epic’s motion. The Company believes it has substantial defenses and intends to vigorously defend itself.

Other Legal Proceedings

The Company is subject to other legal proceedings and claims that have not been fully resolved and that have arisen in the ordinary course of business. The Company settled certain matters during the second quarter of 2024 that did not individually or in the aggregate have a material impact on the Company’s financial condition or operating results. The outcome of litigation is inherently uncertain. If one or more legal matters were resolved against the Company in a reporting period for amounts above management’s expectations, the Company’s financial condition and operating results for that reporting period could be materially adversely affected.

Item 1A. Risk Factors

The Company’s business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition and stock price can be affected by a number of factors, whether currently known or unknown, including those described in Part I, Item 1A of the 2023 Form 10-K under the heading “Risk Factors.” When any one or more of these risks materialize from time to time, the Company’s business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition and stock price can be materially and adversely affected. Except as set forth below, there have been no material changes to the Company’s risk factors since the 2023 Form 10-K.

[' Rules 13a-15 and 15d-15 under the Exchange Act, that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company’s internal control over financial reporting.

Apple Inc. | Q2 2024 Form 10-Q | 18

PART II — OTHER INFORMATION

Item 1.

Legal Proceedings

Digital Markets Act Investigations

On March 25, 2024, the European Commission (the “Commission”) announced that it had opened two formal noncompliance investigations against the Company under the European Union (“EU”) Digital Markets Act (the “DMA”). The Commission’s investigations concern (1) Article 5(4) of the DMA, which relates to how developers may communicate and promote offers to end users for apps distributed through the App Store as well as how developers may conclude contracts with those end users; and (2) Article 6(3) of the DMA, which relates to default settings, uninstallation of apps, and a web browser choice screen on iOS. If the Commission concludes that there has been a violation, it can issue a cease and desist order and may impose fines up to 10% of the Company’s annual worldwide net sales. Although any decision by the Commission can be appealed to the General Court of the EU, the effectiveness of the Commission’s order would apply immediately while the appeal is pending, unless a stay of the order is granted. The Company believes that it complies with the DMA and will continue to engage with the Commission as it conducts its investigations.

Department of Justice Lawsuit

On March 21, 2024, the U.S. Department of Justice (the “DOJ”) and 16 state and district attorneys general filed a civil antitrust lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey against the Company alleging monopolization or attempted monopolization in the markets for “performance smartphones” and “smartphones” in violation of U.S. antitrust laws. The DOJ is seeking equitable relief to redress the alleged anticompetitive behavior. In addition, various civil litigation matters have been filed in state and federal courts in the U.S. alleging similar violations of U.S. antitrust laws and seeking monetary damages and other nonmonetary relief. The Company believes it has substantial defenses and intends to vigorously defend itself.

Epic Games

Epic Games, Inc. (“Epic”) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California (the “California District Court”) against the Company alleging violations of federal and state antitrust laws and California’s unfair competition law based upon the Company’s operation of its App Store. The California District Court found that certain provisions of the Company’s App Store Review Guidelines violate California’s unfair competition law and issued an injunction enjoining the Company from prohibiting developers from including in their apps external links that direct customers to purchasing mechanisms other than Apple in-app purchasing. The injunction applies to apps on the U.S. storefront of the iOS and iPadOS® App Store. On January 16, 2024, the Company implemented a plan to comply with the injunction and filed a statement of compliance with the California District Court. On March 13, 2024, Epic filed a motion with the California District Court disputing the Company’s compliance plan and seeking to enforce the injunction. The Company has filed an opposition to Epic’s motion. The Company believes it has substantial defenses and intends to vigorously defend itself.

Other Legal Proceedings

The Company is subject to other legal proceedings and claims that have not been fully resolved and that have arisen in the ordinary course of business. The Company settled certain matters during the second quarter of 2024 that did not individually or in the aggregate have a material impact on the Company’s financial condition or operating results. The outcome of litigation is inherently uncertain. If one or more legal matters were resolved against the Company in a reporting period for amounts above management’s expectations, the Company’s financial condition and operating results for that reporting period could be materially adversely affected.

Item 1A. Risk Factors

The Company’s business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition and stock price can be affected by a number of factors, whether currently known or unknown, including those described in Part I, Item 1A of the 2023 Form 10-K under the heading “Risk Factors.” When any one or more of these risks materialize from time to time, the Company’s business, reputation, results of operations, financial condition and stock price can be materially and adversely affected. Except as set forth below, there have been no material changes to the Company’s risk factors since the 2023 Form 10-K.

question: How is the adjusted cost for the Company's marketable securities calculated based on fair value, unrealized gains/losses, and types of securities held?
answer:
The adjusted cost for the Company's marketable securities is calculated based on the original cost of the securities, adjusted for unrealized gains and losses. Specifically, the adjusted cost reflects the following:

1. **Original Cost**: This is the initial purchase price of the marketable securities.
2. **Unrealized Gains**: These are increases in the fair value of the securities that have not yet been realized through a sale.
3. **Unrealized Losses**: These are decreases in the fair value of the securities that have not yet been realized through a sale.

The formula can be summarized as follows:

**Adjusted Cost = Original Cost + Unrealized Gains - Unrealized Losses**

In the provided document, we see that as of September 30, 2023, the total adjusted cost for marketable securities was $173,752 million, which includes various categories of securities such as Level 1 and Level 2 securities. The fair value of these securities, which reflects the current market value, is also provided, along with the specific unrealized gains and losses for each category.

Derivative Instruments and Hedging

The Company may use derivative instruments to partially offset its business exposure to foreign exchange and interest rate risk. However, the Company may choose not to hedge certain exposures for a variety of reasons, including accounting considerations or the prohibitive economic cost of hedging particular exposures. There can be no assurance the hedges will offset more than a portion of the financial impact resulting from movements in foreign exchange or interest rates.

Foreign Exchange Rate Risk

To protect gross margins from fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, the Company may use forwards, options or other instruments, and may designate these instruments as cash flow hedges. The Company generally hedges portions of its forecasted foreign currency exposure associated with revenue and inventory purchases, typically for up to 12 months.

To protect the Company’s foreign currency–denominated term debt or marketable securities from fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, the Company may use forwards, cross-currency swaps or other instruments. The Company designates these instruments as either cash flow or fair value hedges. ground_truth: The adjusted cost for the Company's marketable securities is calculated based on the fair value of the securities, unrealized gains or losses, and the types of securities held. The adjusted cost is determined by taking into account the initial cost of acquiring the securities, any subsequent changes in fair value (unrealized gains or losses), and the specific types of securities held by the Company.
